Evaluation_Questions: What percentage of the reading and other assignments did you complete?
Comments_Questions: How well was the course organized?
How effective was the balance between instruction and discussion?
How well did the assigned papers, reports or other projects reflect the aims of the course?
How did the amount of assigned reading work with weekly discussion?
How did the supplementary materials (files, videos, recordings, etc.) for the course enhance your experience of it?
The course filled a significant gap in your knowledge of the field.
Regardless of whether or not the course is required, would you recommend it to other students in and outside the department?
The course goals were clearly presented.
The instructor has a strong grasp of the course subject matter.
The instructor presented the subject matter effectively.
The instructor was willing to consider diverse points of view.
The instructor was willing to answer pertinent questions.
The grading criteria was clearly explained.
The instructor was available for consultation, discussion and advice.
I would recommend this instructor to other students.
How many of the 14 class meetings did you attend?  Comments:
Please offer additional comments you have on such topics as: what worked best about the course, what improvements you would suggest, etc.
How would you rate the overall usefulness of discussion sections for this class?
Was enough time devoted to discussion sections?
Did you attend all the discussions?
Comments_List: The progression of the course generally follows chronology, which is helpful in organizing one's thoughts on the history.
Paul organizes a thorough course that covers a variety of topics in great detail, though I wish we hadnt spent so much time in England and Germany.
Very clear, well thought-out organizational structure for a complex, broad topic.
I wish the slides on the Canvas were all different slides and not the powerpoint direct from class because some of the slides repeated multiple times during class.
I really appreciate Paul Walsh's organization and care that he puts into the lectures.

Though difficult to employ, some more Q&A would be helpful to keep the lectures engaged. In my experience, a time I saw them work well, they were planned for moments where the professor knew there was typically some confusion. The professor had a pretty good idea of where confusion would happen, so instead of letting the students flock into discussion sections with the same question, he would quickly address them in lecture. The professor I have in mind would also throw out "monkey bar" questions---questions that were designed to move the lecture along, usually factoid in nature.
The lecture format is not the best way for me to learn but it was nice to also have discussion.
I really enjoyed my small groups.  They were the icing on the cake. It was really wonderful to discuss YSD and theater with people from different departments.
I really enjoyed Maria and Nahuel's discussion sections this year.

The time between instruction and discussion classes was balanced well, however I've felt a discrepancy in how different TA's use their time; while some offer games and engaging discussions related to the material, others sort of just wait for the students to ask or say something, offering few insights.

There was little to no discussion during the lecture portions of class, which I guess is in theory the point of lecture but shouldn't be the point of learning theater history. Often discussion, which was always amazing, wouldn't address some of the topics discussed in class so some questions would just never go answered.
I had an excellent experience with the way Nahuel and Paul's teachings went together.
I think the paper should be optional. If someone doesn't do well on the midterm than they should have to do the paper. I understand it in the fall but not so much in the spring. Just a thought.

I enjoyed writing the papers but thought it was unfortunate that the only way students could illustrate their understanding of the material was through essays, either in test form or in an assigned paper.
The paper was an appropriate assignment.
I don't think I gained any more from the paper than I did the weekly readings. Probably more from the weekly readings.
The papers and tests require a deep amount of thought and care.
The reading load was well balanced.
I appreciated the weeks when discussion would do it's own thing but still discuss the topic aside from the direct the reading.
Maybe watch more performance of plays?  It makes it easier to digest and more time effective.
Any extra recordings were super helpful to get context especially because I am much more of a visual learner.
I didn't use any of them and I was fine in the class.
I appreciate the extra materials Paul posts to supplement optional learning.

I've given a lot of thought to this. I have an idea that's more of an approach and less technical. I sense an "imparting knowledge" skew to the course. I would be interested in seeing the course take a "follow the curiosity" approach. It would activate me in a way where I might want to follow topics discussed after they've been discussed. More things might stick? Just a thought. Obviously this is all very hypothetical.
I knew very little about theater history and now i know a lot!
I had taken theater history classes prior. If anything it helped me learn something about other students at the school during discussion section.

Not having a strong theater background, I am excited about the depth and alternative topics we cover. Perhaps a reading list before the course begins of things that are not covered, but we "should know by now" could be provided like the supplemental readings to fill in some of the gaps.
A lot of information.  I will not retain all of it, since I don't use it on the reggie.
It might be easier to digest if someone was taking it optionally.
If they are into history, then yes I would.
I would  recommend it to people that had little knowledge of theater history.
Yes, I would strongly recommend this course.
Yes.
No, unless they really really like history or have no concept of it and want to learn it
Yes! It can be challenging at times, especially when my department needs pile up, but the lectures and discussions are so fruitful.
For people who want to learn this of their own volition yes.  Directors, designers, actors, dramaturgs, playwrights, yes.  TD&P and theater majors maybe not so much.
I appreciate the stated objectives at the beginning of each class.
Paul was great!

Paul has an extensive knowledge of the field and keen analysis. He is making a concerted effort to diversify the cultures this course covers, while understandably focusing on the origins of the American theater.
There was one day Paul said he didn't have learn how to pronounce some words so it was okay. Which seemed weird cause Paul is generally really on point, but that was off putting.
Some of the lectures were super packed and that was hard in terms of taking much information in on the topic.
While I am built for courses like Drama 6 I know that other humans had a hard time taking in the information as quickly as it was given.

Please please please give students access to the paper that you are reading during discussion. It would be a lot better to be able to read those with the slides when studying for context. Especially for people that don't have English as a first language, following along during the class can be impossible sometimes.
Hard to follow the lectures at times.

It appears that the course material has grown more diverse over time. The most uncomfortbale day in class was when Paul was scheduled to teach on culturally specific theaters in America and he had not finished the PowerPoint and rushed through the final content. While I dont think this was Pauls intention, the rushed nature of the final slides made it seem like those theater practioners were insignificant and not worthy of our attention.
There was rarely time for questions and questions during the lecture were not allowed
Thanks, Paul!
Paul is a very thoughtful teacher, and he is generous with his time for people that seek out further explanations.

I would even propose that the Dramaturgs could provide useful perspectives to the rest of YSD. Seeing dramaturgs in their element (even if they already have a mastery of the material) could be very helpful for the rest of the school.
All!
I attended 13 of 14.

Dear Paul, 
This is Danilo Gambini. I checked the "decline" box in all the questions because it makes more sense to me to write without a frame. 
It was very clear to me the amount of passion, work and dedication you put into this class, the preparation of the material and the constant revision of the subjects - including EDI, a preoccupation that appears and have to be honed (at least for the next few years) while we struggle as a society to make the world more just.
The structure of the class is very clear as is all of its components, and it is very effective as an academic course. So, I would have no complaints there.

My question is specifically about us having such structure in this program. Most of us are here coming from artistic careers and decided to take a time to lapidate our artistry. Very few of us have any academic interest, and those who have (the dramaturges mostly) do not take this class.
So, most of this investment you put into this whole course, ends up washing down the drain of our over-busy brains. 
What I would see as a class that could inspire our hearts, clash our contemporary beliefs with ancient ones, ignite ideas - ends up being a sequence of bureaucratically taking exams that, I am so sorry to say, are a high-school-type-of-worry instead of an artistic torment (the only worry I find useful to have at this point of my life).
What I would say is that - of course, this is my very own opinion - the classes structures should not change at all. But the evaluation system could be a device of artistic ignition. Maybe a paper could be: propose one of the plays we had to read for the semester for a regional theater production,or the cab even, or design costumes and set for one of them, or create an avant-garde movement nowadays and make a manifesto, or imagine how a shakespeare play would have been staged back then... well, you know what I mean!  
This semester short paper was an example of this kind of evaluation, and I found myself much more invested in exploring the play, which ended up with me contacting the playwright, having a skype meeting with him and securing the rights for another one of his plays to produce at the cab next year. Such artistic explorations in your class could not only inform and inspire our time here, but open new paths for our careers - something that I truly believe does not happen when our efforts are on memorizing names, dates, or short sentences that explain vaguely and superficially concepts that sometimes we do not understand at all.  
Most of all, this reply of mine is my resistance to make any aspect of theater dull. Exams are the apex of dullness for me. The very concept of having a "right way" or "right answer" goes deeply against what I believe the soul of our art form is: there is no right or wrong, there is only life. Whatever happens on stage - and on life - just IS. If we do not establish something as right, the wrong is impossible. 
I truly believe that by de-academicizing the structure of grading  you could make your class a much more powerful tool that the students could use directly in their artistic praxis. 

I hope you don't find this reply too aggressive. This is not my intention. I probably only have strong feelings about this because I also really enjoyed the classes and wished I could have had more artistic outcomes from it. 

Have a great summer!
Danilo

Provide the paper Paul is reading from to students. Don't make going to class a requirement if that lecture reading is provided. Some people just literally can't learn and take in from a lecture/talk at you learning environment and would just be better reading that lecture on their own.

I enjoyed the discussion sections but my experience varied wildly by semester. Nahuel was a brilliant TA who made the readings and course content come alive. Ilya seemed uncomfortable leading the discussions but my group was a powerhouse and because of them, I had a great second semester group, as well.
It varies on who your TA is. I had a very challenging experience with Ilya and do not feel like it assisted my learning. Nahuel truly helped me excel in this course.
Yep!
Yep!
I missed one section.
All but one.
I was out of town for 2 of them
yes
